contentrichtext.text: {{about|the publishing company|the legal term|in open court}} {{Infobox publisher | image = | parent = [[Carus Publishing Company]] | status = | founded = 1887 | founder = Edward Hegeler | successor = | country = [[United States]] | headquarters = [[Chicago]] | distribution = [[Publishers Group West]] | keypeople = | publications = [[Book]]s | topics = philosophy | genre = | imprints = | revenue = | numemployees = | nasdaq = | url = {{URL|http://www.opencourtbooks.com}} }} The '''Open Court Publishing Company''' is a [[publisher]] with offices in [[Chicago]] and [[La Salle, Illinois]]. It is part of the [[Carus Publishing Company]] of [[Peru, Illinois]]. ==History== Open Court was founded in 1887 by [[Edward C. Hegeler]] of the Matthiessen-Hegeler Zinc Company, at one time the largest producer of [[zinc]] in the [[United States]]. Hegeler intended for the firm to serve the purpose of discussing religious and psychological problems on the principle that the scientific world-conception should be applied to religion.<ref>{{Cite CAB|Hegeler, Edward C.}}</ref> Its first managing editor was [[Paul Carus]], Hegeler's son-in-law.<ref name="Fields138">Fields 1992, pg. 138</ref> For the first 80 years of its existence, the company had its offices in the [[Hegeler Carus Mansion]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.chicagoreader.com/chicago/power-house/Content?oid=905535 |work=Chicago Reader |author=Jeffrey Felshman |title=Power House |date=May 31, 2001}}</ref> Open Court specializes in [[philosophy]], [[science]], and [[religion]], and was one of the first [[university press|academic press]]es in the country. It was one of the first publishers of inexpensive editions of the classics.<ref name="Fields138" /> It also published the journals ''Open Court'' and ''[[The Monist]]''â€”the latter is still being published as of 2010. ==Popular culture & philosophy series== One of Open Court Publishing's best-selling series is its semi-annual ''Popular Culture & Philosophy'' series, under the editorship of George Reisch. Volumes on the philosophy underpinning such television shows as ''[[Seinfeld]]'', ''[[The Simpsons]]'' and ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'' propelled the series into the limelight, and have invited many imitators since, including ''The [[Wiley-Blackwell|Blackwell]] Philosophy and Pop Culture Series''<ref>[http://blackwellpublishing.com/seriesbyseries.asp?ref=PPPZ The Blackwell Philosophy and Pop Culture Series]. Accessed January 29, 2008</ref> and The University Press of Kentucky's own Philosophy titles.<ref>[http://www.kentuckypress.com/viewsubject.cfm?Group=175 The University Press of Kentucky Philosophy books].
